attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
A physical stock take was done on 28/05/2025, with the objective of determining of whether internal controls were working effectively to minimise risks and whether physical stock items agreed with those in the SAP system. 

Physical stock count showed the following variations.

Ø  Bread stock had a variance of -30 pieces.

Ø  Polybags had +638 pieces

Ø  White flour had -1.59 Kgs

Ø  Brown flour had +3.70 Kgs

Ø  Utto had +1.83 Kgs

Ø  Other raw materials had insignificant variations as seen below:
attributes.recommendation:
Branch management should strengthen stock control measures and improve the monitoring of polybags by variety to minimize individual and cumulative variances

 Branch management should also introduce stricter cut-off procedures to prevent future  discrepancies.
attributes.effect: The current stock movement controls are effective however variations noted might indicate gaps in proper recording and this needs to be checked. While this do not pose significant financial risk at present, they could indicate opportunities for process refinement.

value: Variations were minimal we will ensure nil variation by ensuring proper recording is done
We will work to minimise variations by emphasizing on ShiftWise stock counts and proper recording of raw materials and finished product movement.

In a prior audit report dated 08 April 2025 polybags had a variance of -1,025 pieces, finished product had a variance of +92.75 Loaves, Wheat Bran had +1.009 Kgs and yeast had -10.536 grams.

Other raw materials had insignificant variations.
Current

As part of the internal audit process, a physical stock take was conducted on 28 May 2025 to assess the effectiveness of internal controls related to inventory management. The objective was to verify the accuracy and reliability of inventory records maintained in the SAP system by comparing them with actual physical stock on hand. This exercise was critical in identifying discrepancies that could indicate control weaknesses, errors, or potential stock management issues.

The physical stock take revealed both positive and negative variances across several inventory items. While some discrepancies were minor and within acceptable tolerance levels, notable variances—such as a shortfall of 30 bread pieces and an excess of 638 polybags—suggest potential gaps in stock recording or handling processes.
Operations/Production Department

To determine if stock movement controls are working effectively to minimize risk.

To determine if Stock as per SAP is in agreement with physical stock.

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
Dough weight

Weight check on dough was done to determine if the branch was complying with the standard dividing range. An 800g CTW batch was used as the sample, as it was being divided at the time of the spot check.

It was noted that for 800 g CTW correct weight was 38%,31% were underweight and 31% were overweight with an average weight of 915.76 which was slightly below the dividing range of 916-920 g as seen below:

Table 2:Dough weight.

 

b) Packed Bread.

  A spot check on packed bread ready to be sent to the market were weighed randomly to determine if they were of correct weight as per the KEBs Standard weights.

 From the sample selected significant underweights were as seen:

ü  600 g Barrel White had 60% underweights with an overall average weight of 583.55 which was below the 588 g.

ü  800 Butter had 19% with average Overall average weight of 793.95.

ü  400 g Long had 57 % with an average weight of 390.69 g.

ü  400 CTW had 51% with an average weight of 391.59 g.

Table 3:Bread weights.
attributes.recommendation:
Branch management should enhance Spot checks on both dough and packed bread to ensure dividers and slicers are complying with standard weights to eliminate cases of underweight. 

Slicers should keenly observe First in first out to prevent cases of overcooling of bread that results in underweights.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties for non -compliance if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials.

value:
This is noted we emphasize on random spot checks to ensure dividers are consistent with the dividing ranges.

There was also trainee oven men and dividers.

We had a challenge during renovations which has resulted in interruptions in slicing sections which has caused jam which led to overcooling of bread.We are working hard to ensure there are no underweights in the branch.

This is noted we emphasize on random spot checks to ensure dividers are consistent with the dividing ranges.

There was also trainee oven men and dividers.

  We had a challenge during renovations which has resulted in interruptions in slicing sections which has caused jam which led to overcooling of bread. We are working hard to ensure there are no underweights in the branch.

In a prior audit report dated 08 April 2025, cases of underweights were as seen below:

200g OTC had 12.50%

-400g Long had 38%

-400 CTW had 43%

-400 BRW had 53%

400 S/N had 24%

-600 BRW had 28%

-800 BT had 30%

-800 BRW had 52%.
Current

A spot checks were conducted on dough weights and packed bread to evaluate compliance with internal production standards and Kenya Bureau of Standards (KEBS) weight requirements. The objective was to ensure that dough portions met the standard dividing range and that finished bread products adhered to regulatory weight specifications before distribution to the market. These checks are vital in maintaining product consistency, customer satisfaction, and regulatory compliance.

The audit identified inconsistencies in both dough and packed bread weights. While 39% of the dough samples fell within the acceptable weight range, the overall average (915.76g) was slightly below the standard range of 916–920g, with nearly equal portions under and overweight. More significantly, a review of packed bread revealed substantial underweight issues across several varieties. For instance, 600g Barrel White had 60% underweight samples, and the 400g Long and CTW varieties had 57% and 51% underweights respectively, indicating systemic non-compliance with KEBS weight standards. These discrepancies pose risks to regulatory adherence and customer trust. Corrective action, including stricter monitoring should be taken.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if branch was complying with the standard dividing range and to determine if they were packing bread of correct weight as per the KEBS.

attributes.title: Bread damages analysis
attributes.description:
Production and Market Damages.

An analysis of production and market/supermarket damages was done for a period of 43 days from 15 April 2025-28 May 2025 to determine whether they were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% to total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively.

 The analysis showed that production damages was at 0.22% which was above the allowable threshold of 0.2% with a cost implication of Kshs 10,731.29 while market damages stood at 0.26% which was within the allowable limit 0.5%

Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings.

Table 4:Production Damages.

 

N/B: The analysis above is exclusive of 252 Oven Damages.

 

Table 5:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should ensure correct production procedures are followed to minimize lapses that could result in excess damages.

Market damages well controlled by having frequent meetings with sales team on proper bread handling.
attributes.effect:
• Production damages exceeded the limits by 0.02% which means that the company lost a revenue of Kshs 10,731.29

  • Market damages were within the allowable limits which implies that the sales team are handling bread in proper ways.

value:
Tins are due for replacement it has contributed to excess damages; request has been sent.

Market damages well controlled by having frequent meetings with sales team on proper bread handling.
We will work on producing bread of good quality to ensure production damages are within the allowable limits of 0.2%
Current

An audit was conducted on production and market/supermarket damages covering a 43-day period from 15 April 2025 to 28 May 2025. The objective was to assess whether the levels of product damages remained within acceptable internal Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), set at 0.2% of total production for production damages and 0.5% of total sales for market damages. This analysis aimed to evaluate operational efficiency, waste management, and the effectiveness of handling procedures throughout the production and distribution processes.

The analysis revealed that production damages stood at 0.22%, slightly exceeding the allowable threshold of 0.2%, resulting in a cost implication of Kshs 10,731.29. Although the deviation appears minimal, it indicates a need for improved quality control and handling during the production process. On the other hand, market damages were within the acceptable limit at 0.26%, well below the 0.5% KPI, demonstrating adequate control in the distribution chain. While market-related losses are currently manageable, the slight excess in production damages suggests room for operational improvements, especially in minimizing avoidable product losses and controlling associated costs.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if production  and Market damages are within the allowable limits of 0.2% of total production and 0.5% of total sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
An analysis of both Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 43 days from15th April 2025- 28 May 2025 to determine the branch’s utto consumption, average yield was as per the set Branch BOM and to determine if there were any instances of remixes that reduces the quality of bread.

 After examining the records, the following were noted;

Ø  Average yield per bag was190.80 loaves per bag which was below the branch BOM of 194

Ø  Utto consumption was at 100%.

Ø  Average production was 120.59bags per day representing 77.30% of target which is 156 bags per day (Branch Capacity).

Ø  No cases of remixes were noted for the audited period.

The table below illustrates the findings;

Table 6:Mixing chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation:
Branch should ensure branch average yield is complied with.

Branch should work on onboarding, more customers to ensure full production capacity is achieved.
attributes.effect:
• Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was under utilized.

  • No remixes implies that the branch was producing bread of Good quality.

value:
Production of Grande was high due to high sales hence the target yield of 194 could not be achieved because the average yield for Grande is 189, which brought the overall yield down Production was based on the branch's average sales of 120 units, so full capacity could not be reached due to the lack of a ready market

There were no remixes, there is effective production planning carried out by the branch supervisors.

Production of Grande was high due to high sales hence the target yield of 194 could not be achieved because the average yield for Grande is 189, which brought the overall yield down.

        Production was based on the branch's average sales of 120 units, so full capacity could not be reached due to the lack of a ready market.

  There were no remixes, there is effective production planning carried out by the branch supervisors.

In a prior audit report, it was noted that Average yield was at 190.79 Loaves per bag, Utto consumption to bags was 100%,12 tins of remixes were noted, average production was at 122.46 bags representing 78.50%
Current

An internal audit was carried out on the mixing charts and their summaries over a 43-day period from 15 April 2025 to 28 May 2025. The objective was to assess the branch’s adherence to the Bill of Materials (BOM), specifically evaluating utto consumption, average production yield per bag, daily production volumes, and the occurrence of remixes—which can compromise product quality. This analysis provides insights into operational efficiency and process compliance in the production area.

The audit revealed that while utto consumption was accurately aligned at 100%, the average yield per bag was 190.80 loaves, falling short of the expected BOM yield of 194 loaves. Daily average production stood at 120.59 bags, achieving only 77.30% of the set branch capacity (156 bags/day), indicating underutilization of production capacity. Importantly, no remixes were recorded, which is positive in terms of maintaining bread quality. However, the lower yield and underperformance in production targets suggest areas for improvement in process efficiency and capacity utilization.
Operations/Production Department
• To determine the branch’s utto consumption, average yield was as per the set Branch BOM and to determine if there were any instances of remixes that reduces the quality of bread.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Production efficiency was done for a period of 43 days from   15 April 2025 to 28 May 2025 to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

It was noted that the average production efficiency was 3.92 bags per production worker as illustrated in the table below;

Table 7:Production Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should allocate production workers as per production target shift wise to ensure set efficiency is achieved.
attributes.effect: The branch Production workers did not achieve efficiency leading to hiring of 117 excess workers with a cost implication of Kshs.127,334.36.

value: Production efficiency was affected by Oven breakdowns and renovations done in the branch; we will ensure proper follow up of production process to ensure KPI is achieved.
Production efficiency was affected by Oven breakdowns and renovations done in the branch; we will ensure proper follow up of production process to ensure KPI is achieved.
During prior audit report average production efficiency was at 4.10 bags per production worker, excess workers who were hired were 103 with a cost implication of Kshs.111,919.80.
Current

An internal audit review of production efficiency was conducted for the 43-day period from 15 April 2025 to 28 May 2025. The aim was to determine whether the branch's production team was meeting the set Key Performance Indicator (KPI) of 4.3 bags per worker per day. This metric is crucial in assessing labor productivity, optimizing staffing levels, and controlling operational costs.

The analysis showed that the average production efficiency achieved was 3.92 bags per worker, falling short of the set target of 4.3 bags. Consequently, this resulted in the hiring of 117 excess production workers beyond what would have been required at target efficiency levels. The cost implication of this shortfall was estimated at Kshs 127,334.36 over the review period. These findings highlight the need for improved workforce management, targeted performance monitoring, and possibly retraining to ensure staff productivity aligns with operational targets and cost expectations.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if production workers were achieving their set KPI of 4.5 bags per production  worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Packing efficiency was evaluated for a period of 43 days from April 14, 2025, to May 28, 2025, to assess whether the hired packers were meeting the target efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

It was noted that the average packing efficiency stood at 84.72 crates per packer as illustrated below;

Table 8:Packing efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch should ensure hiring of packers for each shift should be based on the number of bags produced in the previous shift. This approach will help the branch meet its targets.
attributes.effect: The branch packers did not attain efficiency of 97 crates per packer which implies that allocation was not done as per the prior shift loaves produced, this led to hiring of 98 extra workers with a cost implication of Kshs.89,376

value: For the last two months we have recruits who have been undergoing training this has affected efficiency.
We will work on producing bread of good quality to ensure production damages are within the allowable limits of 0.2%
In the prior audit report dated 8th April 2025, it swas noted that packing efficiency stood at 81 crates per packer.
Current

A review of packing efficiency was conducted for the period from 14 April 2025 to 28 May 2025 to assess whether the number of packers hired aligned with the set performance benchmark of 97 crates per packer per day. The audit focused on evaluating whether actual output justified labor utilization, identifying any inefficiencies that may have contributed to unnecessary staffing costs.

The analysis revealed that the average packing efficiency achieved was 84.72 crates per packer, falling short of the set KPI of 97. As a result, the branch engaged 98 more packers than required to meet the actual production volume, leading to a cost implication of Kshs 89,376 during the audit period. These findings point to a need for improved labor planning and productivity monitoring in the packing section to align workforce deployment with output levels and minimize excess labor costs.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if packing workers were attaining their KPI of 97 crates.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
A spot check in the cash office was carried out with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

Cash had nil variation, however there was a pending IOU of Kshs.2000 dating 29/04/2025 for Paul Kiamba traffic police facilitation that was past the 3-day clearance policy.
attributes.recommendation:
The cashier should maintain the controls.

 A follow up should be done on the pending IOU to be cleared.
attributes.effect: Cash controls are working effectively however for pending IOUs should be followed for clearance.

value: Cash controls to be maintained.
Cash controls to be maintained.
In the prior audit report, it was noted that all cash was all accounted for however there was a pending IOU worth Kshs.14,530 in the name of Francis Omullo Mechanic
Current

A spot check was conducted in the cash office to verify the accuracy and accountability of cash handling practices. The objective was to ensure that the physical cash at hand was in agreement with the recorded cash flow balance and to assess compliance with internal policies regarding petty cash management and IOU clearance timelines.

The spot check confirmed that the cash at hand matched the cash flow balance, indicating sound cash reconciliation practices. However, one exception was noted: an IOU of Kshs. 2,000, issued on 29 April 2025 for traffic police facilitation (Paul Kiamba), remained uncleared beyond the 3-day policy limit. While the variance is minor, the delayed clearance reflects non-compliance with established procedures and should be addressed promptly to maintain financial discipline and accountability.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if cash h handling controls are working effectively and to determine if Physical cash is in agreement with those reported in the cashflow.

attributes.title: Generator fuel consumption
attributes.description:
Generator fuel consumption for the period of 60 days from 1st April 2025-30th May 2025 was done to determine if fuel consumption was within the standard range, it was noted that fuel consumption was within as compared with prior months as detailed below:

Table 9:Generator fuel consumption.
attributes.recommendation: The controls should be maintained by the management.
attributes.effect: The generator  fuel allocation was well controlled.

value: To be maintained.
To be maintained.
In the prior audit report, it was noted that generator fuel consumption for the month of February was 29.94 L/h which was slightly below as compared with march which was at 37.29 l/h.
Current

An audit review of generator fuel consumption was conducted for the 60-day period from 1 April 2025 to 30 May 2025. The objective was to assess whether fuel usage during the period was within acceptable operational limits by analyzing generator hours run against fuel consumed, and to compare usage trends with previous months to detect any irregularities or inefficiencies.

The audit established that fuel consumption during the period was within the expected range, with a total of 161 litres consumed over 13.89 generator hours, resulting in a consumption rate of 11.59 litres per hour. This rate is consistent with prior periods, indicating effective fuel usage monitoring and no signs of abnormal consumption or wastage. The absence of fuel stock variances also confirms sound fuel management and record-keeping practices.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if generator fuel consumption is within range in comparison with previous months.

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of debtor’s balances was done as of 29th May 2025 to determine if there were any instances of bad debts, Dormant customers and institutions that could pose a risk of default. An outstanding balance of Kshs. 2,535,604.70 was noted which were balances due to institutions and route customers whose are supplied in the evening, and they pay the following day before placing the orders

 It was also noted that there were 6 dormant institutions and 1 dormant customer with balances of kshs 565,387.20
attributes.recommendation: Sales rep should follow up on dormant customers for payments to be made/Cleared from security.
attributes.effect: Dormant customers pose a risk of default if not followed up.

value:
Daily debtors are sent to sales rep for follow up and we also sent reminders for follow up.

Dormant customers have been communicated with sales team for follow up.

Daily debtors are sent to sales rep for follow up and we also sent reminders for follow up.

Dormant customers have been communicated with sales team for follow up.
In a prior audit report total customers outstanding debts was 1,707,837.45 while route customers had balances amounting to Kshs 249,501.50.
Current

An analysis of debtor’s balances as of 29th May 2025 was conducted to assess the credit risk exposure related to outstanding customer and institutional accounts. The review aimed to identify any instances of bad debts, dormant accounts, and customers or institutions whose delayed payments could pose a financial risk to the business. Particular attention was given to balances due from institutions and route customers supplied on credit terms, alongside verification of efforts to recover dormant balances

The analysis revealed a total outstanding debtor balance of Kshs. 2,535,604.70, primarily from institutions and route customers with agreed payment terms. Notably, six dormant institutions and one dormant customer accounted for Kshs. 565,387.20 of this balance, with demand letters issued for recovery. Several accounts marked as “to be cleared” indicate ongoing collection efforts. While most customers adhere to agreed payment cycles, the dormant accounts pose a potential risk and require continued monitoring and follow-up to mitigate possible defaults. Overall, proactive credit management and timely collections remain essential to maintaining healthy cash flows.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if there were any instances of bad debts, Dormant customers and institutions that could pose a risk of default.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption
attributes.description:
Mileage analysis was done for the month May to determine if fuel allocation was done as per the standard rates.

 For the month of May it was noted that fuel consumption was within the standard consumption rates as illustrated in  below:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to ensure fuel allocation is done as per the standard consumption rates and predetermined distance.

value: To be maintained by ensuring proper allocation is done.
To be maintained by ensuring proper allocation is done.

In a prior audit report dated 8 April 2025, it was noted that vehicles fuel consumption was fairly controlled with Town, Mutuati 2 and Timau routes saving of 17.14 litres,

15.17litres and 17 litres respectively.

Further it was noted that Githongo route had over consumed fuel by 20.14litres
Current

An analysis of mileage and fuel consumption for the month of May 2025 was conducted to assess whether fuel allocation across various routes adhered to the set standard consumption rates. The review focused on comparing actual fuel consumption against expected benchmarks, highlighting any savings or additional costs.

This mileage analysis for the month of May 2025 was conducted to evaluate whether fuel allocation across various transport routes adhered to the established standard consumption rates. The objective was to ensure efficient fuel usage, identify any deviations, and highlight areas of fuel savings or excess consumption. By comparing actual mileage and fuel consumption data against benchmark standards, the analysis aims to support effective fleet management and cost control.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if fuel allocation is done as per the set Consumption rates and predetermined distance in Kilometers.
